title: Design native task management in genie-cli - eliminate bd dependency
description:
Brainstorm and design how genie-cli should natively handle task management without relying on bd CLI.

Goals:
- Store all data in .genie/ folder (no .beads duplication)  
- Friendly task-based CLI that doesnt require bd commands
- Native integration with term work/workers/close commands
- Session resume capability using Claude session IDs

Explore:
- What bd functionality do we actually need?
- Can we embed bd as a library or reimplement the essential parts?
- How should the data model look?
- Whats the ideal UX for task management?

description:
## Summary
Change bd to use `.genie/` folder instead of `.beads/` for storing beads data. This would consolidate all genie-related data into a single folder.

## Requirements
1. Add support for configurable data folder name (e.g., via `BD_DIR` env var or config)
2. Default to `.genie` in genie-cli context
3. Make initialization automatic as part of genie-cli startup
4. Migration path for existing `.beads` data

## Investigation Needed
- [ ] Find where `.beads` folder name is defined in bd source
- [ ] Determine best approach: env var, config file, or both
- [ ] Check if this can be contributed upstream or needs a fork

## Acceptance Criteria
- `bd` commands work with `.genie/` folder
- Existing repos with `.beads/` continue to work (backward compat)
- genie-cli auto-initializes the folder when needed

title: CLI reorganization: LLM-friendly command structure
description:
## Problema

A CLI do genie-cli cresceu organicamente e tem:
- ~35 comandos top-level (difícil lembrar)
- Duplicação (term watch = term orc watch)
- Inconsistência (spawn vs work, ship vs close)
- Camadas misturadas (tmux primitivos junto com workers)
- Descoberta ruim (sem agrupamento lógico)

## Proposta: Estrutura LLM-First

**Princípio:** 90% do uso é sobre **workers** e **tasks**. Tmux é detalhe de implementação.

### Quick Access (top-level)
```
term spawn [skill]       # Cria worker
term work <id|next>      # Cria worker vinculado a task
term ls                  # Lista workers + sessions
term read <worker>       # Lê output do worker
term approve [worker]    # Aprova permissão
term answer <w> <choice> # Responde pergunta
term dashboard           # Status live
term close <id>          # Fecha task + cleanup
term kill <worker>       # Força kill
```

### Subcomandos
```
term task <sub>          # beads: create, update, ship, close, ls
term session <sub>       # tmux: new, ls, attach, rm, exec, send, read, info, split, window, pane
term batch <sub>         # parallel: status, list, cancel
term daemon <sub>        # sync: start, stop, status, restart
```

### Power Tools
```
term watch <worker>      # Real-time events
term events [pane-id]    # Claude Code events
term parallel [ids...]   # Spawn múltiplos (rename spawn-parallel)
term council             # Dual-model deliberation
term orc <sub>           # Orquestração baixo-nível
```

### Aliases
```
term w <id>    → term work <id>
term s [skill] → term spawn [skill]
term d         → term dashboard
term a         → term approve

# Skill shortcuts
term brainstorm → term spawn brainstorm
term forge <id> → term work <id> --skill forge
```

## Breaking Changes (com aliases de migração)

| Antes | Depois |
|-------|--------|
| term new/rm/exec/send/split/info | term session <sub> |
| term create/update/ship | term task <sub> |
| term spawn-parallel | term parallel |

Aliases mantidos para backwards compat com deprecated warning.

## Benefícios

1. Top 8 comandos cobrem 90% do uso
2. Namespace lógico (session pra tmux, task pra beads)
3. Aliases curtos (w, s, d, a)
4. Help contextual por subgrupo
5. Descoberta natural via --help
